a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and N :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[13/14, -1/7, 3/14], [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], [3/14, 3/7, 5/14]])"
and h1 : "N = vec 3 [1, 2, -3]"
and h2 : "matrix_vector_mult A N = 0"
shows  "N = vec 3 [1, 2, -3]"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix}$ is the normal vector, its projection is the zero vector.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to
 \begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and N :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[13/14, -1/7, 3/14], [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], [3/14, 3/7, 5/14]])"
and h1 : "N = vec 3 [1, 2, -3]"
and h2 : "matrix_vector_mult A N = 0"
shows  "N = vec 3 [1, 2, -3]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix A with elements: [[13/14, -1/7, 3/14], [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], [3/14, 3/7, 5/14]], and a 3-component vector N with elements: [1, 2, -3], if multiplying the matrix A with the vector N results in a zero vector, then show that the vector N is indeed [1, 2, -3].

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix([[13/14, -1/7, 3/14], [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], [3/14, 3/7, 5/14]])"
and h1 : "v = vector [1, 2, -3]"
and h2 : "M *v v = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1, 2, -3]"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix}$ is the normal vector, its projection is the zero vector.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to
 \begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes M :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix([[13/14, -1/7, 3/14], [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], [3/14, 3/7, 5/14]])"
and h1 : "v = vector [1, 2, -3]"
and h2 : "M *v v = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1, 2, -3]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix M with rows [13/14, -1/7, 3/14], [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], [3/14, 3/7, 5/14], and a vector v [1, 2, -3]. If the product of M and v is a zero vector, confirm that the vector v is [1, 2, -3].

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real mat"
assumes h0 : "P = mat_of_rows_list 3 [[13/14, -1/7, 3/14], [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], [3/14, 3/7, 5/14]]"
shows  "normal_vector P = vec_of_list [1, 2, -3]"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix}$ is the normal vector, its projection is the zero vector.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to
 \begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real mat"
assumes h0 : "P = mat_of_rows_list 3 [[13/14, -1/7, 3/14], [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], [3/14, 3/7, 5/14]]"
shows  "normal_vector P = vec_of_list [1, 2, -3]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
Given that the matrix P is defined as:

```
P = [[13/14, -1/7, 3/14],
     [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], 
     [3/14, 3/7, 5/14]]
```

Find the normal vector of P. The final answer is the vector [1, 2, -3].

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "A = (1/14) *\<^sub>R (vector [[13, -2, 3], [-2, 10, 6], [3, 6, 5]])"
and h1 : "A *v v = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1, 2, -3]"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix}$ is the normal vector, its projection is the zero vector.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to
 \begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "A = (1/14) *\<^sub>R (vector [[13, -2, 3], [-2, 10, 6], [3, 6, 5]])"
and h1 : "A *v v = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1, 2, -3]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find a vector v such that when it is multiplied by the matrix A (which is 1/14 times the matrix with rows [13, -2, 3], [-2, 10, 6], [3, 6, 5]), the result is the zero vector. The solution is the vector [1, 2, -3].

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes matrix :: "(real, 3) vec list"
assumes h0 : "matrix = [(13/14, -1/7, 3/14), (-1/7, 5/7, 3/7), (3/14, 3/7, 5/14)]"
shows  "normal_vector matrix = (1, 2, -3)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof

 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to
 \begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes matrix :: "(real, 3) vec list"
assumes h0 : "matrix = [(13/14, -1/7, 3/14), (-1/7, 5/7, 3/7), (3/14, 3/7, 5/14)]"
shows  "normal_vector matrix = (1, 2, -3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the normal vector of the matrix with rows (13/14, -1/7, 3/14), (-1/7, 5/7, 3/7), (3/14, 3/7, 5/14). The final answer is (1, 2, -3).

a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix}$ is the normal vector, its projection is the zero vector.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to
 \begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "P = (1/14) *\<^sub>R ((13, -1, 3), (-1, 5, 3), (3, 3, 5))"
and h1 : "v = (1, 2, -3)"
and h2 : "P *v v = 0"
shows  "v = (1, 2, -3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix P with entries (13, -1, 3), (-1, 5, 3), (3, 3, 5) and scaled by 1/14, and a vector v with entries (1, 2, -3), find the vector v such that the matrix product Pv equals the zero vector. The final answer is v equals (1, 2, -3).

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[13/14, -1/7, 3/14], [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], [3/14, 3/7, 5/14]])"
and h1 : "\<forall> w. w \<in> plane A \<longrightarrow> v \<bullet> w = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1,2,-3]"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix}$ is the normal vector, its projection is the zero vector.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to
 \begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3" and v :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[13/14, -1/7, 3/14], [-1/7, 5/7, 3/7], [3/14, 3/7, 5/14]])"
and h1 : "\<forall> w. w \<in> plane A \<longrightarrow> v \<bullet> w = 0"
shows  "v = vector [1,2,-3]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a $3\times3$ matrix $A = \begin{bmatrix} 13/14 & -1/7 & 3/14 \\ -1/7 & 5/7 & 3/7 \\ 3/14 & 3/7 & 5/14 \end{bmatrix}$ and a vector $v$ such that for all vectors $w$ in the plane defined by $A$, the dot product of $v$ and $w$ is $0$, find $v$. The final answer is $v = [1,2,-3]$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes projection_matrix :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "projection_matrix = matrix([[13 / 14, -1 / 7, 3 / 14], [-1 / 7, 5 / 7, 3 / 7], [3 / 14, 3 / 7, 5 / 14]])"
shows  "normal_vector_of_plane = vector [1, 2, -3]"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix}$ is the normal vector, its projection is the zero vector.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to
 \begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes projection_matrix :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "projection_matrix = matrix([[13 / 14, -1 / 7, 3 / 14], [-1 / 7, 5 / 7, 3 / 7], [3 / 14, 3 / 7, 5 / 14]])"
shows  "normal_vector_of_plane = vector [1, 2, -3]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given the projection matrix $\begin{bmatrix}13/14 & -1/7 & 3/14 \\ -1/7 & 5/7 & 3/7 \\ 3/14 & 3/7 & 5/14 \end{bmatrix}$, find the normal vector of the plane. The final answer is the vector [1, 2, -3].

a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix}$ is the normal vector, its projection is the zero vector.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to
 \begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real^3^3" and n :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "P = (13/14, -1/7, 3/14, -1/7, 5/7, 3/7, 3/14, 3/7, 5/14)"
and h1 : "P * n = 0"
shows  "n = (1, 2, -3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem:
Find a vector $n$ such that when it is multiplied by the matrix $P$, the result is a zero vector. The matrix $P$ is given by $\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
13/14 & -1/7 & 3/14 \\
-1/7 & 5/7 & 3/7 \\
3/14 & 3/7 & 5/14
\end{array}\right)$. The final answer is the vector $n = (1, 2, -3)$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = (1/14) *\<^sub>R (vector [vector [13, -2, 3], vector [-2, 10, 6], vector [3, 6, 5]])"
and h1 : "A *v x = 0"
shows  "x = vector [1, 2, -3]"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix}$ is the normal vector, its projection is the zero vector.
 Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to
 \begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = (1/14) *\<^sub>R (vector [vector [13, -2, 3], vector [-2, 10, 6], vector [3, 6, 5]])"
and h1 : "A *v x = 0"
shows  "x = vector [1, 2, -3]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find a vector $x$ such that when it is multiplied by the matrix $A = \frac{1}{14} \times \begin{bmatrix} 13 & -2 & 3 \\ -2 & 10 & 6 \\ 3 & 6 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$, the result is the zero vector. The final Answer is $x = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{bmatrix}$.

natural problem:
The matrix for projecting onto a certain plane $P,$ which passes through the origin, is given by
\[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1}.\]Find the normal vector of plane $P.$  Enter your answer in the form $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix},$ where $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are integers, $a > 0,$ and $\gcd(|a|,|b|,|c|) = 1.$
natural solution: Since $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix}$ is the normal vector, its projection is the zero vector.

Thus, \[\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.5} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{13}{14} & -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{3}{14} \\ -\frac{1}{7} & \frac{5}{7} & \frac{3}{7} \\ \frac{3}{14} & \frac{3}{7} & \frac{5}{14} \end{pmatrix} \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1} \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\frac{13}{14} a - \frac{1}{7} b + \frac{3}{14} = 0,$ $-\frac{1}{7} a + \frac{5}{7} b + \frac{3}{7} c = 0,$ and $\frac{3}{14} a + \frac{3}{7} b + \frac{5}{14} = 0.$  These reduce to

\begin{align} 13a - 2b + 3c &= 0, \\ -a + 5b + 3c &= 0, \\ 3a + 6b + 5c &= 0. \end{align}Subtracting the first two equations, we get $14a - 7b = 0,$ so $b = 2a.$  Then \[-a + 10a + 3c = 0,\]so $c = -3a.$  Hence, \[\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a \\ 2a \\ -3a \end{pmatrix} = a \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},\]so the vector we seek is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}.$
